summary: Manolo Ray was an exile leader of the People's Revolutionary Movement (Movimiento Revolucionario del Pueblo - MRP). He opposed a U.S. invasion of Cuba, advocating instead for internal resistance supported by a broad base within Cuba. He believed that funds and trained exiles were more crucial than a direct invasion to overthrow Castro. His statements were relayed by the British Service to the CIA. He was against a Cuban invasion, asserting that internal resistance, supported by a broad base within Cuba, is the preferred method to overthrow Castro.
significance: Manolo Ray's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as a prominent Cuban exile leader and his opposition to a U.S. invasion of Cuba, favoring internal resistance instead. His views and activities were monitored by the CIA, as evidenced by the telegrams and messages documenting his statements. His stance on how to deal with Castro's regime provides insight into the diverse opinions and strategies within the Cuban exile community during that period, which is relevant to understanding the broader political landscape surrounding the JFK assassination.
